questions.text: Which of the following investigations can be used in osteoporosis? Multiple completion 1. DEXA 2. Bone scan 3. Quantitative CT 4. Serum chemistry What is the answer?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 1,3,4 IOC for osteoporosis? DEXA T- SCORE <-2.5 ? Osteopenia ? T-Score ? between -1 to - 2.5 ? Bone scan has no role to play in osteoporosis. ? Quantitative CT ? DONE to look at BMD especially for vertebra. ? Serum chemistry would be helpful too.

questions.text: A 7 year old child presented with lymphadenopathy, skin lesion and following skull radiograph. Which of the following drugs is commonly used in this scenario?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Vinblastine Multiple lytic lesions in a skull of child ? LANGERHANS CELL HISYIOCYTOSIS ? geographic skull/ beveled edges. ? Lytic lesions in skull of old man ? Multiple Myeloma. For patients with single system LCH, the choice of therapy is generally made based on the site of involvement and number of lesions with an aim to minimize toxicity. Treatment options include single agent prednisone, the combination of vinblastine and prednisone, curettage of bone lesions, and topical therapy for skin lesions. Alternatively, a subset of patients may select close observation with treatment upon progression. ?Patients with multisystem LCH should be encouraged to participate in a clinical trial. For patients who are not candidates for a clinical trial or for those who choose not to participate in a clinical trial, usually suggested initial induction chemotherapy with vinblastine plus prednisolone or cytarabine alone (Grade 2C). Subsequent therapy is dependent on disease response at six weeks and whether "risk organs" (ie, hematopoietic system, liver, and/or spleen) were involved at the time of diagnosisa )

questions.text: Patient with peptic ulcer disease was having abdominal pain since many days, worse since last few hours. Xray is shown, what is to be done next?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) IV ?uids and laparotomy Gas below diaphragm? perforation

questions.text: 30 year old with BMI 18 with progressive di?culty in swallowing in both solids and liquids for 8 months. Barium swallow is shown to you. What other investigation should be done in this patient
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) UGI endoscopy + Manometry CT PET done for staging of CA esophagus 24 hour pH monitoring done in GERD. This is classic picture of achalasia cardia Manometry is indicated for con?rmation of diagnosis. Achalasia: barium swallow study may be used to con?rm oesophageal dilatation, in addition to assessing for mucosal abnormalities. Findings include: 1. bird beak sign or rat tail sign 2. oesophageal dilatation 3. tram track appearance: central longitudinal lucency bounded by barium on both sides 4. incomplete lower oesophageal sphincter relaxation that is not coordinated with oesophageal contraction 5. pooling or stasis of barium in the oesophagus when the oesophagus has become atonic or non-contractile (a late feature in the disease) 6. uncoordinated, non-propulsive, tertiary contractions

questions.text: Young male post Road tra?c accident and is brought to causality with low GCS score. Has features of raised ICT. NCCT brain and spinal imaging were normal. No pelvic fracture, Fast is negative.What could be probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Diffuse axonal Injury NORMAL CT, LOW GCS ? DAI. Diffuse axonal injury (DAI), also known as traumatic axonal injury (TAI), is a severe form of traumatic brain injury due to shearing forces. It is a potentially di?cult diagnosis to make on imaging alone, especially on CT as the ?nding can be subtle, however, it has the potential to result in severe neurological impairment. The diagnosis is best made on MRI where it is characterised by several small regions of susceptibility artifact at the grey-white matter junction, in the corpus callosum, and in more severe cases in the brainstem, surrounded by FLAIR hyperintensity.

choices.text: Immediately shift the patient to OT for thoracotomy
Immediate needle thoracotomy in the 5th intercostal space
Large bore needle in 5th Intercostal space followed by ICD tube in 5th Intercostal space.

questions.text: 25 year old male came to emergency after Road tra?c accident. He is unable to speak full sentences, with hyper-resonant note on percussion and hypotension. CXR is shown, what is the appropriate initial management of this case?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Large bore needle in 5th Intercostal space followed by ICD tube in 5th Intercostal space. This a classic case of tension pneumothorax. A tension pneumothorax will have the same features as a simple pneumothorax with a number of additional features, helpful in identifying tension. These additional signs indicate hyperexpansion of the hemithorax: 1. ipsilateral increased intercostal spaces 2. contralateral shift of the mediastinum 3. depression of the hemidiaphragm

questions.text: 40 year old male is suffering from increasing di?culty in bending forward and inability to look upwards. CT scan is performed , what is the most likely diagnosis?

X-Ray of forearm will be given, will have increased bone density, with ligamentous and interosseous membrane ossi?cation. RA - CLASSICALLY INVOLVES– MCP, PIP & C1,C2 CERVICAL VERTEBRA AT ATLANTO-AXIAL JUNCTION

questions.text: In eFAST which other part is included apart from abdomen?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Thoracic cavity M-mode USG of chest for pneumothorax? Barcode appearance Normal ? Seashore appearance An extended FAST or "eFAST" scan is now standard of care, and is performed by incorporating two views assessing the anterior thorax : Anterior pleural views • the anterior pleura is assessed for the presence or absence of lung sliding as a sensitive, but non-speci?c, indicator of a traumatic pneumothorax • the probe is placed in a sagittal orientation in the midclavicular line between the clavicle and diaphragm • anterior and lateral interrogation of interspaces 5-8 bilaterally is recommended

questions.text: 40 year old male patient with mucopurulent cough underwent CT examination, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Bronchiectasis Bunch of grapes sign ? bronchiectasis ? Cystic fibrosis ? upper lobe predominant. ? Pulmonary infarct ?seen as opacity not lucency ? Hydatid will have water lily appearance bronchiectasis Chest x-rays are usually abnormal but are inadequate in the diagnosis or quanti?cation of bronchiectasis. Tram-track opacities are seen in cylindrical bronchiectasis, and air-?uid levels may be seen in cystic bronchiectasis. CT and HRCT especially excel at demonstrating the airways and is able to a greater or lesser degree to distinguish some of the various underlying causes. A number of features are helpful in diagnosing bronchiectasis: 1. tram- track sign 2. signet ring sign 3. string of pearls sign 4. bunch of grapes sign

questions.text: Which of the following doesn’t use ionizing radiation?

questions.text: Empty thecal sac sign is seen in?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Arachnoiditis The "empty thecal sac sign" is a radiological finding seen on MRI, particularly in cases of arachnoiditis. It refers to the appearance where the nerve roots of the cauda equina are clumped peripherally within the thecal sac, leaving the center of the sac appearing empty. This happens due to inflammation and fibrosis of the arachnoid mater, which causes adhesions and displacement of the nerve roots. Arachnoiditis can result from prior spinal surgery, infection, trauma, or intrathecal injections. Incorrect Options: A. Vertebral osteomyelitis: This is an infection of the vertebral bone and intervertebral disc space. MRI may show vertebral destruction, abscess formation, or disc space narrowing, but it does not show the empty thecal sac sign. C. Tethered cord syndrome: This involves abnormal attachment of the spinal cord, often seen as a low-lying conus medullaris with stretching of the cord. It causes neurological symptoms but does not produce the empty thecal sac sign. D. Discitis: This is inflammation of the intervertebral disc space, often infectious. It may show disc space narrowing and enhancement on MRI, but like osteomyelitis, it does not cause the nerve root clumping or empty thecal sac sign seen in arachnoiditis.

questions.text: Most probable diagnosis on the below xray is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Cervical rib The given x ray is cervical xray AP view showing cervical rib Rib arising from 7th cervical vertebra.

questions.text: Name the type of investigation shown in the below image.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Myelography Myelography is done by injecting dye into spinal cord through lumbar puncture. It was previously used to detect spinal cord pathologies. This investigation is now replaced by MRI.

questions.text: The below logo is used to indicate?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Radiation hazard Trefoil symbol denotes radiation hazard with each leaf of trefoil separated by an angle of 60 degree.

choices.text: Useful in young females with dense breasts
Differentiates between solid and cystic lesions in the breast
Can be used for mammographically undetectable clinical non palpable breast mass

questions.text: Which of the following is not an advantage of USG over Mammography?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Can be used for mammographically undetectable clinical non palpable breast mass USG is useful in young females with dense breasts, it differentiates between solid and cystic lesions in the breast, and USG-guided biopsy can be done. However, a very small percentage of cases can be diagnosed by USG with are mammographically undetectable and clinical non-palpable.

questions.text: Identify the abnormality found in the ultrasound image shown below
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Phrygian cap Phrygian caps are the most common congenital anatomic variant of the gallbladder. It denotes folding of the fundus back upon the gallbladder body and is asymptomatic with no pathological significance.

questions.text: An MRCP image is shown below. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Choledocholithiasis The given image is a MRCP (T2W MRI). The terminal calculus is seen as a filling defect. Hence the diagnosis of Choledocholithiasis. MRCP is the best non-invasive diagnostic technique and ERCP is the gold standard as it is both diagnostic as well as therapeutic.

questions.text: Identify the fracture site in the xray shown below:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 6th and 7th rib In the chest xray, ribs appear as light grey strips. The anterior part of the rib is more oblique and the medial part cannot be seen as it ends with costal cartilage. The posterior part of the rib is more horizontal and the attachment of the rib with the vertebra can be easily made out.

questions.text: A patient presented with dysuria and pain in the back. His lumbar spine xray shows the below finding. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Hyperparathyroidism The given image shows parenchymal calcification, which is seen in Nephrocalcinosis. It is divided into several types, with differing etiologies, based on the distribution: • Medullary nephrocalcinosis: 95% • Cortical nephrocalcinosis : 5% • partial, combined cortical and medullary nephrocalcinosis. Hyperparathyroidism in an important cause of Nephrocalcinosis.

questions.text: Banana sign in USG is associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Spina bifida Banana sign in USG depicts the cerebellum tightly wrapped around the brainstem. It is seen in majority of the fetuses with spina bifida. Lemon shaped skull and Lumbar meningomyelocele also point towards diagnosis of Spina bifida.

questions.text: Child with breathlessness. Identify the foreign body seen
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: Identify the marked ligament
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: Most sensitive for parathyroid tumour imaging
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Tc-99m Sestamibi SPECT (Single Photon Emission Computed Tomography) is the most sensitive imaging modality for detecting parathyroid tumors, particularly parathyroid adenomas. This technique uses the radiotracer Tc-99m sestamibi, which is preferentially taken up by hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue due to its high mitochondrial content and metabolic activity. When combined with SPECT, the scan provides three-dimensional localization of the abnormal gland, significantly improving sensitivity and spatial resolution compared to planar sestamibi imaging alone. This makes it especially valuable in cases of ectopic glands or in patients undergoing reoperation. Ultrasound (USG) is often used as an initial, non-invasive modality, but it is less sensitive, particularly for deep or ectopic glands. MRI, while useful in complex or recurrent cases, is not as sensitive as Tc Sestamibi SPECT for routine detection. Therefore, Tc Sestamibi SPECT is the preferred and most sensitive imaging choice for parathyroid tumor localization.

questions.text: Contrast that can be given in pts of chronic renal failure
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Uttasound contast In patients with chronic renal failure, iodinated contrast agents (whether ionic or non-ionic) carry a high risk of contrast-induced nephropathy. Gadolinium-based contrast used in MRI is also risky because it can cause nephrogenic systemic fibrosis (NSF) in patients with significantly reduced GFR. Ultrasound contrast agents (usually microbubble-based) do not rely on renal clearance for excretion and have no nephrotoxic effect, making them the safest option in these patients. Why other options are incorrect: A. Ionic iodinated contrast – Highly nephrotoxic, especially in reduced kidney function; risk of contrast-induced nephropathy is highest. B. Non-ionic iodinated contrast – Less nephrotoxic than ionic but still unsafe in severe chronic kidney disease. D. Gadolinium – In severe renal failure, increases risk of nephrogenic systemic fibrosis, which is potentially debilitating.

questions.text: Identify the marked blood vessel in this MR Angiogram-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The occipital artery is a posterior branch of the external carotid artery that travels toward the back of the scalp. In MR Angiograms, if a vessel is seen coursing posteriorly and laterally, behind the level of the ear and toward the occipital region, it most likely represents the occipital artery. In the provided image, the yellow arrow points to such a vessel — positioned behind the vertical midline of the skull, consistent with the occipital artery’s anatomical course. This vessel is not part of the intracranial circle of Willis system and lies superficially, confirming its identity. Option A (Superficial temporal artery) is incorrect: The superficial temporal artery is another terminal branch of the external carotid artery, but it runs anterior to the ear and ascends over the temporal region of the scalp. On an MR Angiogram, this artery appears more anteriorly and laterally compared to the occipital artery. In the given image, the vessel is clearly posterior, which does not match the typical anterior course of the superficial temporal artery, making Option A incorrect. Option B (Basilar artery) is incorrect: The basilar artery is a major midline intracranial artery, formed by the union of the vertebral arteries. It travels along the ventral surface of the brainstem and is located deep in the posterior cranial fossa. On MR Angiography, it appears as a central vertical vessel, not lateral or superficial. The vessel marked in the image is superficial and lateral, not midline or deep, which eliminates the basilar artery from consideration. Option C (Middle meningeal artery) is incorrect: The middle meningeal artery is a branch of the maxillary artery, which enters the skull through the foramen spinosum and supplies the meninges. It courses along the inner table of the skull, especially in the temporal and parietal bones, often with a characteristic "H-shaped" branching pattern. It is generally not visualized clearly on routine MR Angiograms unless specialized imaging is done. Moreover, its path is within the skull, not superficially visible like the vessel marked in the image. Thus, this makes Option C incorrect.

questions.text: History of pain at the left side of chest since yesterday after he slips on the stairs and falls on his Left side. Rib fractures are seen involving which ribs
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The 7th and 8th ribs are part of the middle and lower rib cage, which are most vulnerable to fractures during lateral (side) impacts, like falling on the side of the body. These ribs are: • Located in the posterolateral chest wall. • Less protected than upper ribs, which are shielded by muscles and the scapula. • More mobile than the upper ribs, making them more likely to fracture under blunt trauma, especially from a fall. • In this case, the patient fell on his left side, so the impact would likely affect the lateral and lower lateral ribs — typically the 6th to 9th ribs, with the 7th and 8th being common sites. Why Other Options Are Incorrect: A. 4th, 5th rib: These are upper ribs, protected by the pectoral muscles and shoulder girdle. They are less likely to fracture from a side fall. B. 5th, 6th, 7th: While the 6th and 7th ribs are getting closer to the impact zone, the 5th rib is still too high. This option is less precise than option C. D. 9th, 10th rib: These are lower ribs, and while they can be involved, they are more flexible due to their floating nature and are less commonly fractured than the 7th and 8th in lateral trauma.

questions.text: 9 year old child with skin rashes, endocrine abnormalities including hyperthyrodism and multiple bone lesions with increased uptake on bone scan
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) McCune-Albright syndrome is a rare genetic disordered originally recognized by the triad of polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, precocious puberty, and cafe-au-late spots. A variety of endocrine disorders, including hyperthyroidism, acromegaly, phosphate wasting, and Cushing syndrome are now considered as part of the endocrinopathies seen in this disorder. The variable constellation of symptoms arises from a somatic activating mutation of the GNAS gene, which is present in many tissue types. Direct from class notes.

questions.text: Which of the following investigation is contraindicated in pregnancy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) CT scan uses ionizing radiation, which can harm the developing fetus. MRI and USG are safer options in pregnancy. Therefore, CT scan is contraindicated.

questions.text: A35 year old patient presented with the colicky pain and diagnosed to have ureteric stone. Which of the following is the best diagnostic investigation in this case?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Non-contrast CT KUB is the most sensitive and specific test for ureteric stones. It can detect radiolucent stones not visible on X-ray. Hence, NCCT KUB is the investigation of choice.

questions.text: A child presented with seizure and CECT is done and show below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Neurocysticercosis appears as ring enhancing lesions with central dot (scolex) on CECT. It is common in endemic areas and presents with seizures. Thus, neurocysticercosis is the diagnosis.

questions.text: Most useful investigation for localization of parathyroid adenoma:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Sestamibi scan is highly sensitive for parathyroid adenomas. It uses Tc-99m radiotracer to localize hyperfunctioning glands. Therefore, it is the investigation of choice.

questions.text: Identify the shown investigation modality:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) X-ray defecogram is used to evaluate pelvic floor disorders during defecation. It involves contrast instillation into the rectum and X-ray imaging. Hence, the investigation shown is an X-ray defecogram.

questions.text: Honda sign (H) seen on STIR MRI in-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Sacral insufficiency fractures appear as vertical lines in sacral ala. Often seen in osteoporotic patients and may mimic metastasis. Hence, the diagnosis is sacral insufficiency fracture.

questions.text: Eye of tiger appearance on MRI is associated with:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Eye of tiger sign on MRI is due to iron deposition and gliosis. It is classically seen in Pantothenate Kinase Associated Neurodegeneration (PKAN). So, PKAN is the correct diagnosis.

questions.text: A male patient with diarrhea since 8months with shown CT finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Chronic diarrhea with CT showing loss of haustrations suggests ulcerative colitis. It typically involves the colon in a continuous pattern. Thus, ulcerative colitis is the likely diagnosis.

questions.text: Based on the provided X-ray image, identify the type of thyroid malignancy:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Follicular carcinoma often shows capsular and vascular invasion. It may present with cold nodule or bone metastasis. So, the diagnosis is follicular carcinoma.

questions.text: 17 year old with swelling and pain in leg. Xray revealed sunburst appearance and codman triangle. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Sunray appearance and codman triangle are typical xray signs of osteosarcoma
